Package edu.uky.games.physics_game

package edu.uky.games.physics_game
The foundation on which you will build a very simple 2D video game physics engine.

In this tutorial, you will create a very simple physics game similar to KickUps that involves clicking on a bouncing ball in an attempt to knock it into a basket in the center of the screen.

The skeleton of a 2D physics engine is provided here, including:

  • GameFrame and GamePanel for drawing rectangles and circles and getting user input.
  • Vector for representing vectors and points and for doing basic vector math operations.
  • A suite of helpful Utilities.
  • A customizable list of Settings.
  • A PhysicsEngine which you will write, which is responsible for updating the position of each body before each frame and for handling collisions.
  • The components to build an efficient broad phase collision detection algorithm.

Key parts of the code are missing. You will fill in these missing code fragments with help from in-line comments.

It is recommended that you work in this order:

  • PART I: Body Movement
  • Step 1: Write the high-level method PhysicsEngine#simulate(RigidBody[] bodies), which simulates all the bodies in the game.
  • Step 2: Fill in the low-level method PhysicsEngine#simulate(RigidBody body), which simulates an individual body.
  • Checkpoint: Now the ball should move, but it will fall through the floor because there is no way to handle collisions.
  • PART II: Handling Collisions
  • Step 3: Add the basic information needed for collisions to PhysicsEngine#collide.
  • Step 4: Make objects react to collisions by filling in more of PhysicsEngine#collide.
  • Checkpoint: Now the ball should bounce off of other objects, but it may stick to or sink into them.
  • Step 5: Move overlapping objects apart by filling in PhysicsEngine#correctPosition.
  • Checkpoint: Now the ball should bounce realistically.
  • Step 6: Make the game react to user input by filling in GamePanel#controller#mousePressed.
  • Checkpoint: Now the physics should be totally working; however, the game should be performing exactly 28 narrow phase collision checks per frame.
  • PART III: Efficient Broad Phase Collision Detection
  • Step 7: Write the code to initialize the collision detection lists in PhysicsEngine#initialize.
  • Step 8: Comment out the naive collision detection code in PhysicsEngine#detectCollisions and fill in the more efficient code.
  • Step 9: Fill in PhysicsEngine#checkX to scan for bodies that overlap on the X axis.
  • Step 10: Fill in PhysicsEngine#checkY to verify that bodies also overlap on the Y axis.
  • Checkpoint: Collision detection should work again, and the game should be performing less than 1 narrow phase collision tests per frame.
  • Related Packages
    Package
    Description
    edu.uky.games.physics_game.collision
    Efficient broad phase collision detection using the popular Sweep and Prune method.
    edu.uky.games.physics_game.physics
    Simulated bodies that move around in a 2D space and change direction when they collide.
  • Classes
    Class
    Description
    GameFrame
    The high-level container for a GamePanel.
    GamePanel
    A JPanel which displays all the objects in the game and collects user input.
    Settings
    Settings for this project.
    Utilities
    A suite of helpful utility functions.
